title: verbosity
content:
The act definitely wins my kudos.

Oddly enough, though, I still don't think the UK's gone far enough.

Let's go back in history a bit. In the US at one point, some people got upset because those of european descent and those of any other descent were going to separate schools. "Segregation like this," said these upset people, "Should not be permitted." The US Supreme Court disagreed. "Segregation is fine," the Court said, "So long as the facilities are equal." It wasn't until fifty-eight years later that the US finally got around to figuring out that separate is inherently not equal. Schools were integrated.

The main thing I want to pull from that is that separate is not equal. I applaud the fact that same-sex couples in the UK can finally get legal recognition of their union. Why, though, can they not be legally married? Same-sex couples now have the same rights as traditional opposite-sex couplesexcept the word. But what's in a name anyhow? A surprising amount. Consider for example a man who has a lot of sex and a woman who has a lot of sex. The man is called virile. The woman is called a slut. Giving the same thing two different names can lead to very different perceptions of the thing.

But enough on the UK thing. Kudos to Canada, the Netherlands, and the other places who in no way distinguish heterosexual and homosexual couples. I feel somewhat fortunate that my partner is a Canadian citizen.

I think that an interesting question to ask might be what makes a marriage a marriage. Love? Children? Strategy? I'm curious as to what people think, and as to what it is that straight people can do that gays can't.
